newsitem.title: UK: WORLD BONDS- NZ, UK offer real returns, with risk.
newsitem.headline: WORLD BONDS- NZ, UK offer real returns, with risk.

text.p: Yield-hungry investors trying to eke out a decent real return in major bond markets face tough choices in the current low inflation world, analysts said on Friday.

In addition to lower real yields, currency risks in otherwise attractive markets such as New Zealand and Britain and a potential upside inflation bias in Germany from the weaker mark have clouded the issue, they said.
"The intelligent investor ought to be focusing on the issue of real yields," said Michael Derks, cross market fixed income strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
"Real yields are compressed, so you need to ask whether real returns at these levels are going to be justified over time."
Derks said the market that really stood out at present in terms of a healthy real yield was New Zealand, which still has one of the highest yields and lowest rates of inflation in the world.

New Zealand's consumer price inflation was at 1.1 percent in June, while the 10-year bond yield, annualised for international comparison, is currently at 6.96 percent, giving a real yield of 5.86 percent.

That compares with a real yield of 3.87 percent in Germany -- based on 1.7 percent inflation and 5.57 percent nominal yield -- and 4.19 percent in Britain, which saw 2.9 percent inflation in June with a 7.09 percent 10-year yield.
But even in New Zealand, the case is not as clear-cut as it has been, since currency factors threaten to erode returns.
"To the extent that real interest rates are very high, that has attracted a lot of investors to New Zealand," said Kirit Shah, chief strategist at Sanwa International.
"My concern is not an inflation problem...But the currency is already falling versus the dollar which is putting some people off."
Shah said with a large chunk of foreign investment in New Zealand, a snap sell-off by overseas investors could send prices sliding.
He noted the real return in the UK was fairly healthy, but added that was just one factor in a number that influenced investment decisions.
"I'm not so sure people are buying bonds because of real yields only," he said. Sterling's relentless rise and fears of another interest rate rise have kept the big money at bay.

Stephen Englander, international economist and vice-president at Smith Barney in Paris, said despite that, yields in Britain were fairly attractive."Surprisingly, the UK isn't a bad place to be," he said.
"We're afraid the Bank of England may tighten a few more notches, but in terms of yields, levels are attractive."
Shah said potential inflationary pressures in Germany should be sounding alarm bells for Bund investors.
"One has to be very careful in terms of import price inflation," he said, adding that if the mark kept on weakening at its recent pace, it could endanger Germany's impressive inflation record.
But Englander was more sanguine, saying the inflation risk in Germany was minimal at the end of the day. He said medium-term Italian paper looked pretty good in real yield terms.
Englander noted investors in search of serious yields would have to increasingly turn to emerging markets.
"Convergence in Europe has brought down yields in absolute terms as well so there's only a few pockets left you can point to where you can earn a bit of money," he said.
